The sharing of their observations with us gives real hope for change.#The My Place Photography Competition is supported by Historic Environment Scotland and Jessops and is free to enter and is open to schools, youth groups, clubs and home-educated young people.Visit myplacescotland.org.uk for information on how to enter for the  competition.The owners of two Islay distilleries have moved to help restore precious peatland and water resources to ensure drinks production is sustainable in Scotland.Beam Suntory, the maker of Laphroaig, Bowmore and Teacher#s, and its parent company, Suntory Holdings, have announced the launch of the Peatland Water Sanctuary initiative, a large-scale series of peatland restoration and watershed conservation projects.The companies plan to invest more than £ million in the restoration and conservation of , hectares of peatlands by , enough to produce the same amount of peat that Beam Suntory harvests every year in making its Scotch whiskies on an ongoing basis.Once restored and conserved, peatland naturally accumulates by mm per year, and that mm growth spread across , hectares will equate to Beam Suntory’s annual use.The first project is due to begin at Ardmore distillery in November , followed by subsequent projects at Bowmore and Laphroaig, and other distilleries across Scotland.In the first phase, nearly  hectares of peatland in the Ardmore Knockandy Hill north side slope will be restored, with more to follow in . Restoration will also potentially include Malsach Burn Valley as early as .This initial restoration project at Ardmore will be undertaken in partnership with the James Hutton Institute, which is assisting with the research, planning, and execution of the restoration, and Forestry and Land Scotland, which owns the land.

title: from our files november 12 2021
story: A world first is coming to Kintyre, with the announcement of a new hybrid ferry.When the Gigha ferrymen go home at night, they will have to remember to plug the ferry into the mains, for the Tayinloan to Gigha route will get a new passenger and vehicle roll-on roll-off the ferry, which will incorporate a low-carbon hybrid system of diesel, electric and battery power.The other will go to the CalMac service between Skye and Raasay.This is one of two new ferries which are to be funded by the Scottish Government in a contract worth more than £ million.Clyde shipyard Ferguson#s of Port Glasgow has been awarded the contract, allowing it to create more than  new jobs and keep its  current employees.The ferries will come into operation in , a world first for seagoing passenger and vehicle roll-on roll-off ferries.The technology will be cleaner, quieter and cheaper to operate and maintain than ever before.It will help Scotland to meet ambitious climate change targets and demonstrates the vast economic potential of developing green technology and moving to a low-carbon economy.Richard Dean, managing director at Ferguson#s, said the ships should be able to charge from the national grid overnight, drawing on renewable energy.The two ferries will each accommodate  passengers and  cars or two HGVs with a service speed of nine knots.George Taylor, technical director for Caledonian MacBrayne, who was part of the small ferry project team, behind the plans, said: #The introduction of hybrid power units on the next generation of small ferries is an exciting step in our ongoing efforts to improve the environmental impact of our vessels.#TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOArgyll and Bute health officials have confirmed that from this week, Campbeltown Hospital will only deal with emergency deliveries while planned deliveries will take place in Glasgow.Antenatal care will continue to be provided exactly as before, and despite delivering only emergency cases, mothers and babies can stillto hospital for recuperation closer to home.And as for the future of the maternity ward – it is not in doubt.#We retain our firm commitment to a -hours-a-day midwery service and there will be no reduction in beds as a result of the changes in deliveries,# said a trust spokesman.The switching of planned deliveries to Glasgow comes after general practitionersthroughout the Argyll and Clyde Health Board area expressed worries about the safety of births in outlying districts.#Local GPs are anxious that they should have the proper expertise and knowledge to deal with deliveries in the hospitals,# said a health board spokesperson.#They need to keep up their expertise, and to do that with the relatively low number of births is very hard.#The number of births has halved in the past  years with only  babies being born here last year.#If there is an emergency that will be dealt with by the doctors,# the spokesperson added.#What we are talking about here is planned deliveries.#Local GPs made their intentions known in April of this year following professional advice from the Royal College of Obstetricians.Since then they have been advising mums-to-be to deliver their babies in specialist centres such as the Southern General Hospital in Glasgow.FIFTY YEARS AGOA Navy bomb disposal unit raced from Faslane to Carradale on Monday after a Tarbert fishing boat had picked up no fewer than four mines in its nets in Kilbrannan Sound.The vessel reported the matter to Southend Coastguard and the Navy men were alerted.It was later discovered that the mines were of the practice type, but could still explode.The bomb disposal unit discharged the four mines at sea.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOThe annual meeting of the Nursing Society in affiliation with Queen Victoria#s Jubilee Institute for Nurses was held in the Christian Institute on Monday afternoon, Reverend Charles McLean BD presided.The annual report was read by the hon secretary Mrs AH Gardiner.In submitting this the st annual report, the committee congratulate themselves on the increasing support they are receiving in their efforts to alleviate, by the services of a trained nurse, cases of sickness and suffering among the community.The work is carried on most successfully by Nurse Rankin.For some months Nurse Rankin was unfortunately off work, owing to ill-health, and her work was undertaken voluntarily by her sister Nurse M Rankin, in addition to her own work as health visitor.The committee desire to express their gratitude to Nurse M Rankin for the work she undertook and accomplished during her sister#s convalescence.Nurse Rankin ed in June, restored in health, and has since been on duty and performed her work with unfailing sympathy and success.A total of  new cases were nursed during the year from st October, , to st October, .Of these cases,  were medical,  surgical  recovered, three were removed to hospital, and  remain on the books of the society.A total of , visits were paid, and the nurse was on duty , and-a-half hours.The ordinary income from subscriptions, donations and investments, including interest from the Cordiner Endowment, amounts to £.s d and the expenditure to £.s d.An offer from the Argyll Education Authority of £ per annum as salary to the nurse for undertaking the work of following up treatment for school children under the doctor employed by the Education Authority has just been received and the committee hope to be able to accept this offer, provided the work involved can be accomplished without interfering with the district work.The committee again desire to remind the public that Nurse#s services are at the disposal of anybody requiring trained nursing, but that, in the case of people who are able to do so, the services are expected to be acknowledged by a donation, however small, to the funds of the society.Dr JP Brown testies to the usefulness of the Nurse#s services and said he did not know how the doctors would get on without her assistance.[Editor#s note: The NHS was still a long way off the National Health ServiceAct  came into effect on July  .]

title: johns lifetime of service to piping honoured
story: John Wilson was awarded the Balvenie Medal for letime services to piping at the Glenfiddich piping championship held at Blair Castle on October .John said: ‘I feel very privileged and honoured to receive this award because I know that there are other people, like me, within the piping world who put something back into piping to improve playing standards and develop the art, particularly within the younger generation.’Speaking at the award ceremony acclaimed Canadian piper, composer and adjudicator Bob Worrall said: #John#s skills as a consensus builder and communicator, along with a clear vision of how to support the growth and improvement of pipe bands have helped us navigate through some potentially dficult times.#He is truly one of the great communicators, someone you would describe as a people person and, who I like to describe, as the people’s friend.#I think all of us as solo piping or pipe band adjudicators are in awe at how John provides adjudication feedback on a critque sheet. I call him the ‘Master of the Metaphor’.#The winning of this prestigious award comes after John was inducted into the Scottish Traditional Music Hall of Fame two years ago to mark his contribution to performance and teaching.John was originally taught by his father Pipe-Major William Wilson, who also  taught many young players in the Campbeltown area.He started competing at the age of eight and won all juvenile events in Scotland, several times over.At the age of  John began studying piobaireachd under Pipe-Major Donald MacLeod and this relationship lasted  years.When John turned to professional competition at the age of just  he won the Argyllshire Gathering medal for the senior Strathspey and reel competition.He went on to win the gold medal at the Northern Meetings at his first attempt and  subsequently won almost every major, solo award including the gold medals at Oban and Inverness plus the senior piobaireachd and the former winners’ march, Strathspey and reel events at both meetings.John joined the police in  and became pipe sergeant of the Strathclyde Police Pipe Band during a period of many major championship victories, which included six consecutive world championship wins.  In total he won  world pipe championships with the band.John is now retired from the police and concentrates on teaching at home and abroad.He is also a senior adjudicator for solo piping and he is currently the convener of the Royal Scottish Pipe Band Association adjudication  management board.

title: letters november 12 2021
story: The East Kintyre Community Council was dismayed by last week’s fawning article congratulating Amazon on its first UK Wind farm.Whilst the community councils and residents of Kintyre support renewable energy systems, we believe that Kintyre is being literally pillaged with little thought, consultation or recompense for the communities being affected.The Scottish Government created Best Practice Principles, which it declares will #help deliver lasting economic and social benefits to host communities#.But these lofty principles are being ignored: the government neither mandates these or even make a genuine effort to encourage their use.Rather, huge, international, profit-focussed companies are running rings around theEKCC asks what exactly are Councillors Armour, Kelly and Colville doing about it other than standing back and applauding the demise of the communities they are supposed to represent.These companies are not offering community shared ownership as the Scottish Government suggests and, given the lack of incentive to do so, rarelyever will.Rather, they will devastate our tourism industry and the quiet enjoyment of our homes, and then they will leave as quickly as possible with their profits.Much like similarly powerful oil firms in the last century, the profits will go where and the ‘host’ communities will be exploited to the fullest extent.Whilst you are giving these companies a round of applause, have you considered what devastation they are bringing to our communities Argyll and Bute’s own Landscape Capacity Study insists that no turbine should ever be higher than  metres, but this is about to thrown out of the window with the Narrachan application.If this goes ahead, a precedent will be set and eventually the spine of Kintyre will be scarred with wind turbines ultimately reaching  metres in height, crowned with flashing red lights. The already-fragile roads will erode further and noise pollution will continue.How much employment are they bringing to the area  So far, it appears to be almostWorse, this transient ‘employment’ block books our hotels and BBs, damaging our tourism industry and threatening our economic viability.Besides trying to halt the continuing escalation in turbine heights, EKCC is nowThis utterly massive, industrial eyesore is not only a further affront to tourism, it is a huge health risk to the surrounding residential area.Any very basic risk assessment would rule this site out: frequently flooded glens, electricity and explosive lithium batteries do not go well together.There is another, more suitable site near Crossaig but it would cost these profit-focussed developers more to build.These latest planning applications are currently with Argyll and Bute Council and theYet Councillors Armour, Colville and Kelly repeatedly fail to attend EKCCShould Planning approve these applications, then the councillors should be aware that much like when the rising water reaches these lithium batteries it will likely cause and explosive reaction and their votes will disappear.Time to step up councillors and do your job.At our recent AGM, Kintyre Food Bank agreed that I should thank all the people who have been so generous to us with their time, donations and money.This has been a very dficult year for many people the work of the food bank has been particularly important.It could not have stayed open to meet the need without the wonderful assistance you have given.In preparation for Christmas, we will be having a collection at Tesco on Thursday and Friday .We are grateful to Tesco for all the help given to the food bank.The fuel prices in Campbeltown are outrageous.At .p a litre for petrol and .p a litre for diesel, they are the dearest to be found anywhere and the excuse it costs more due to our location is unacceptable.In September, the price of petrol started at .p and has continued to rise.I was on holiday to Inverness in September and prices for petrol were .-.p.I would say that these prices blow our local garage#s excuses out of the water.As there is no competition here, they are ripping the people of Campbeltown off and they are about the dearest in the UK.Last week, it was reported that the dearest in the UK was .p per litre and yet we were being charged .p.Parkinson’s UK Scotland is encouraging people of working age with Parkinson#s in Argyll and Bute to meet with others and find out more about living well with the condition at a free online event this month.Drop-in sessions covering a range of topics will start on November  and be run flexibly over two weeks.Many of the sessions will be led by people with Parkinson#s and their partners, who developed the programme based on their experiences of being diagnosed with Parkinson#s at a younger age.Parkinson#s affects people of all ages, and we know that there are around , people under  who#ve been diagnosed with Parkinson#s in Scotland, with around  of them spread across Argyll and Bute.Now more than ever, we want younger people with Parkinson#s to know that they are not on their own, and find out more about things that can help.Our face-to-face events are always oversubscribed, and attendees have told us that having information about Parkinson#s and things that can help with day-to-day le is invaluable.Meeting other people facing similar challenges, concerns and opportunities can make a massive dference, and we hope this online event will be as helpful in these dficult times.To find out more, please check out our  programme: https:prksn.uk nytYFor further details and to request a booking form, please call    or email scotland@parkinsons.org.uk

title: liveargyll pedal for pudsey
story: On Friday November , at Victoria Hall, Campbeltown, members of the community are being invited to go the distance for charity and test their own indoor cycling fitness by taking a ramp test.Similar to beep tests but on a bike, the Functional Threshold Powerramp test will not only check basic fitness levels but also calculate an FTP score which can then be used to help track progress and motivate participants throughout future workouts.Anyone interested can turn up any time between -.am and am-.pm and donations for Children in Need will be welcomed.Instructors will be on hand to guide and motivate people throughout the test.A special Coach by Colour taster Torque Endurance class will also be held at the hall from .-.pm, in aid of Children in Need. To book contact Aqualibrium on  .

title: musselburgh man shares nostalgic verses about wee toon home
story: A Campbeltown man now living in Musselburgh has shared with the Courier a couple of nostalgic poems he penned about his hometown.Jim McRobert says that although he only lived in Campbeltown for  years, he has always called it home.A fan of writing poetry, he has penned many verses during lockdown, some of which were published at Edinburgh International Book Festival.As well as nostalgic pieces reflecting on his younger years, Jim also writes about current affairs like Covid- and US politics, some of which we have published in the past.This week, both verses relate to nostalgic Wee Toon tales, the first recounting a supernatural encounter local miners had in a Kintyre cave.#In the early s, many of the new men to the town had come to work in the mine and had all moved from the Denny region,# he said.#They had grown up together and often behaved like teenagers. For example, when there was snow and ice on the roads, they made an ice slide on Tomaig Road from almost the top, down to the Meadows Farm, and they would let off fireworks in the street.#Here is another memory which was never mentioned again##Jim#s second verse, about the enjoyment of a walk around Campbeltown, was written in response to a request from some of his Kintyre friends.

title: thought for the week november 12 2021
story: Memory, however, needs prompts, ranging from shopping lists to diary or calendar entries for signicant anniversaries or events.November  or the Sunday nearest, calls us annually as a nation to remember the sacrice and heroism of two terrible world wars and many conflicts since.The purpose of Remembrance, however, is not simply historical but to bring out a sense of thankfulness and gratitude for what was achieved.On May , , the Prime Minister Winston Churchil, announced on the radio at pm that the war in Europe was over. This became known as VE Day.The records of our church show that on VE Day plus two, a service of thanksgiving included a reading of Psalm , which had been printed in full the previous day on the front page of the Daily Record – yes, the Daily Record, which at that time was owned by Kemsley Newspapers.The generation who attended acknowledged the generous response of a gracious God to the national days of prayer, held during the war and attributed deliverance to His watchful care over us as a nation through many dark days.Remembrance also features in the title deeds of the building in which we worship.The founding fathers determined to build a place, primarily for believers to follow the example of the first disciples and to meet on the first day of the week, to call to mind in bread and wine, the self-sacrice of the Lord Jesus on the cross and the blessing for the whole world which would flow from it.

title: whats new at campbeltown picture house 7
story: Wes Anderson’s The French Dispatch is a love letter to journalists set in an outpost of an American magazine in a fictional th-century French city and brings to le a collection of stories published in The French Dispatch. Written and directed by Wes Anderson, the film stars Benicio del Toro, Frances McDormand, Jeffrey Wright, Adrien Brody, Timothée Chalamet, Léa Seydoux, Tilda Swinton, Mathieu Amalric, Lyna Khoudri, Stephan Park, Owen Wilson, and Bill Murray.The Boss Baby: Family Business Now adults, Tim Templetonis a stay-at-home dad for two adorable daughters, while his estranged brother, Ted , is a big-shot CEO. They come together in an unexpected way when they take a magical formula that transforms them into babies for  hours. Joining forces with Tim#s secret-agent daughter, they must go under cover to prevent an evil genius from turning fellow toddlers into monstrous brats.

title: a great day out in argyll and bute
story: Visitors will be able to take advantage of discounted tickets to businesses participating in the Days Out Incentive Fund.Inveraray Jail is one of the Argyll businesses to receive funding to subsidise the cost of tickets, allowing visitors up to  per cent off admission per ticket up to the value of £.Around  businesses have so far received funding to subsidise the cost of tickets.Administered by VisitScotland on behalf of the Scottish Government, the incentive scheme is aimed at supporting tourism recovery by providing a boost for visitor attractions, day tour excursions and outdoor wildle and adventure activities during the quieter winter months.Businesses are still able to apply for the Days Out Incentive Fund, which is open until the end of November.A dedicated Great Days Out in Scotland page on VisitScotland’s website www.visitscotland greatdaysout will direct visitors to businesses participating in the incentive scheme, as well as showcase the vast range of paid and free visitor attractions, adrenaline-filled outdoor adventures and food and drink experiences on offer throughout the country during the winter.Tourism Minister Ivan McKee said: #With the loss of many international tourists this year due to the pandemic, the launch of the Great Days Out in Scotland campaign will increase local visitor numbers and provide a vital boost to Scotland’s world-class tourism attractions over the quieter winter months.#Scotland’s tourism industry is one of the jewels of our economy and as we begin to carefully emerge and recover from the pandemic, we must work with the tourism industry to seize Scotland’s potential and build an economy for everyone by delivering greater, greener and fairer prosperity.#VisitScotland regional director David Adams McGilp said: #The loss of international visitors over the past year has had a major impact on visitor attractions, tours and activity providers, in Argyll and Bute.#Our regional tourism and events sector needs the support of people living in Scotland.#The Great Days Out in Scotland campaign will help inspire people to brighten up their winter days by taking part in a day out with family or friends at one of the many fascinating visitor attractions or experiences on offer across the region.#Tourism is a force for good, creating economic and social value in every corner of Scotland and enhancing the wellbeing of everyone who experiences it.Tourism makes Scotland richer, economically and socially, and without it, Scotland would be a much poorer place.#Gavin Dick, Prison Governor at Inveraray Jail, said: #As a visitor attraction that has always championed being open all year round, we are particularly grateful for this great initiative by VisitScotland to help our business at this time of year and it is great for our visitors too.#ScotRail is also be running a Buy One, Get One Free ticket offer in November, which can be used in conjunction with the Great Days Out in Scotland campaign.The train operator launched the offer on Sunday November , which will last for two weeks and will be valid for travel from Sunday to Thursday.Look out for more details at www.scotrail free

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: east-lothian-remembrance-events-2021-details-commemorations-around-county
story: Remembrance services were scaled back last year in the face of the coronavirus pandemic.Various restrictions are still in place but services are being held in a number of towns and villages.Provost John McMillan said he was glad some Remembrance events couldthis year.He added: ldquoIt is really important to remember and people remember in their own inidual ways.While most communitiesrsquo events are on Sunday, the occasion will be marked in West Barns on Saturday. Anyone attending should head to the villagersquos war memorial for .am, with the Rev Brian Hilsley, interim moderator and locum at Belhaven Parish Church, giving a brief address at .am. The wreath-laying will then take place and refreshments will be available in West Barns Village Hall.In Haddington on Sunday, St Maryrsquos Parish Church is holding two services. There will be the usual informal all-age service at .am, and at .am an in-person, ecumenical service of Remembrance. Members of the congregations of other churches in the town will join with invited representatives of community groups.A spokesperson for St Maryrsquos said: ldquoBecause our capacity is much reduced, there will be limits on the number of people who can attend in-person. As it was in , the service will be livestreamed.To book a place, text or call   -am or -pm tomorrow .A wreath-laying takes place at the townrsquos war memorial at .am, while wreaths will also be laid in Athelstaneford and at the Ferguson Memorial in Haddington.In North Berwick, St Andrew Blackadder Church hosts a service at .am on Remembrance Sunday. Participating organisations will hold a parade to the church, led by North Berwick Pipe Band, leaving Imperial car park at about .am. After the service, there will be a parade to the war memorial, where the Act of Remembrance and wreath-laying ceremony will take place at about noon.In Dirleton, Remembrance Day will see the rededication of the villagersquos war memorial, which has been restored . The memorial service starts at .am at the monument, led by the Rev David Graham Sir Hew Dalrymple will also give a short address and music will be provided by Lyle Crawford, a senior member of North Berwick Pipe Band.Aberlady will have a short service at the war memorial at am and people are being asked to assemble at .am. There will be representatives from Territorial Army and Marine Commandos, community organisations, church, community councillors and Scouts. There will then be a service in Aberlady Parish Church at .am, taken by visiting minister the Rev John Gordon.Kaye MacAskill, church treasurer, said: ldquoNumbers are still restricted in church, so wersquore not able to have groups of unormed organisations. Itrsquos a small representative group from each of them. Some members of the public will be able to come into church but we canrsquot have a full church this year.In Gullane, there is an lsquoactiversquo Remembrance at the villagersquos war memorial at am on Sunday. Refreshments are available at The Watchman Hotel afterwards.In Dunbar, tea and coffee will be served at Dunbar Royal British Legion from am. The parade of organisations will make its way from High Street to the townrsquos war memorial on Marine Road at .am before a service is held at am. The organisations then make their way back into the town centre.A short service of remembrance will be held at the war memorials beside Athelstaneford Parish Church and Stenton Parish Church at .am on Sunday.At Prestonkirk Parish Church in East Linton, there will be a joint service for all three churches in the parish ndash Stenton, Athelstaneford and Prestonkirk ndash at .am and then at the war memorial at noon.Meanwhile, in Prestonpans, a Remembrance parade will go ahead as normal, with a socially distanced crowd in attendance. The parade marches off from the Legion at .am along Rope Walk to Redburn Road, North Grange Avenue and down West Loan to the war memorial. An upgrade to the square that surrounds the war monument is under way but space will be made to ensure the ceremony can take place.In Cockenzie and Port Seton, a similar parade takes place on Sunday, leaving the Legion at .am and arriving at the village green for .am. The service will be followed by a two-minute silence at am before parading to Cockenzie Old Parish Church. Following a service at the church, the parade willto the Legion, where at about .pm a salute and silence, followed by a lament from the pipe band, will take place.In Longniddry, a church service takes place at Longniddry Parish Church on Sunday at .am.In Tranent, a parade starts from East Lothian Co-operative Bowling Club, down Ormiston Road, High Street, Church Street, Winton Place and High Street to Tranent Parish Church for a service at .am.In Elphinstone, a parade begins at .pm from Elphinstone Minersrsquo Club to Main Street for a gathering at the war memorial, before ing to the minersrsquo club for .pm.In Ormiston, a remembrance service takes place at the village church at .am, while two wreaths will be laid at the side of the building. Following the service, a walk to the memorial will take place where a further two wreaths will be laid.Pencaitlandrsquos church holds a service at .am, followed by the community act of remembrance at the war memorial at noon.In Musselburgh, there will be no official service on Remembrance Sunday at the Mall Fountain but a parade will leave Musselburgh Town Hall at .am to walk to St Michaelrsquos Church, Inveresk, for a service of Remembrance.In Wallyford, a service takes place at St Clementrsquos Church at am. Wreaths will be laid in the church garden at am.

title: appointments-now-needed-east-lothians-vaccine-bus-long-queues-cold
story: The bus, launched by East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnershipas a drop-in service last Tuesday, was attended by more than  people in its first four days of service.It provides Covid- boosters and flu jabs for lsquopriority groupsrsquo, including people aged over  and those who are clinically extremely vulnerable.The bus visited Ormiston Medical Practice on the first two days and Gullane Medical Practice on Thursday and Friday.Photos shared on social media of the bus at its stop in Gullane showed traffic chaos, forcing the police to attend, and some members of the public complained of waits of up to two hours in the cold.A spokesperson for ELHSCP said: ldquoDue to an extremely high level of interest in the service which resulted in long queues, y waiting times and local traffic disruption, ELHSCP has decided to review how the bus operates.ELHSCP will now deliver an outreach programme and the vaccination bus will operate on an appointment referral basis only. Vaccinations will no longer be available on a drop-in basis.The spokesperson added: ldquoOur expectation is that the majority of people living in East Lothian who are eligible will receive their flu and Covid booster vaccinations at one of our clinics in Musselburgh Primary Care Centre or East Lothian Community Hospital in Haddington.ldquoPlease be assured thatyou are over  or clinically extremely vulnerable and have already received your flu vaccination but are now eligible for your Covid booster, you should expect to receive an appointment letter from NHS Lothian in the coming weeks.Members of the public complained on social media of long waits in the cold.One said: ldquoI waited for about one hour and  minutes for my vaccination.ldquoDespite the pressure of numbers, the staff were very efficient and friendly.Another said: ldquoPersonally feel that this could be done in a much safer environment like a golf course or open field away from homes.ldquoRight now, many people who are potentially sick could be spreading the virus [unknowingly] among vulnerable people.Another added: ldquoPeople were standing out in the icy cold wind for hours today, then they sat under a temporary cover attached to the side of the bus to be injected, then sat on chairs in the cold windy shade until they were allowed to leave.The ELHSCP spokesperson said: ldquoIf you are invited to attend an appointment on the vaccination bus, please be aware that:

title: films-screened-tranents-fraser-centre-weekend
story: The trio star in The Last Duel, which focuses on respected knight Jean de Carrouges.When the much-admired squire Jacques Le Gris viciously assaults Carrougesrsquo we, she steps forward to accuse her attacker, an act of bravery and defiance that puts her le in jeopardy.The film, directed by Ridley Scott, is shown at pm with a second screening at the Tranent venue next Thursdayat pm.Meanwhile, therersquos also plenty to entertain youngsters.The Gruffalorsquos Child takes to the big screen todayand Ronrsquos Gone Wrong is shown on Saturday.The Gruffalorsquos Child sees Gruffalorsquos daughter embark on a journey to find the Big Bad Mouse.Ronrsquos Gone Wrong is the story of Barney, a socially awkward middle-schooler, and Ron, his new walking, talking, digitally connected device, which is supposed to be his lsquoBest Friend out of the Boxrsquo.Both films are shown at pm.

title: scottish-liberal-democrat-leader-alex-cole-hamilton-visits-haddington-farmers-market
story: Alex Cole-Hamilton, who took on the role earlier this year, stopped off at the market on the townrsquos Court Street.The MSP for Edinburgh Western was campaigning, with local authority elections taking place next year.

title: youngsters-enjoy-spooky-halloween-party-haddington
story: A group of friends who meet in Haddingtonrsquos Costa decided to put on a party for youngsters in the townrsquos bowling club.One of the members of the group said: ldquoWe decided after the past  months or so wersquod put on a wee party for the kids in the group, as all kids had been doing really great throughout lockdown.ldquoIt was the first party we have held, and hopefully next year we might do a ticket event, and raise funds for charity.ldquoWe all had a fantastic time, it was enjoyed by everyone.Prizes were awarded to spookiest, cutest and best costumes.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-november-8-12-1996-1971-1921
story: lsquoRESIDENTS flee storm terrorrsquo was the front page of the East Lothian Courier on November , .Hurricane-force winds brought chaos to East Lothian on Wednesday when nearly  people were evacuated after a roof was blown from flats at Prestonpans, some schools had to close, roads were blocked by falling trees and many homes were left without electricity.Weathermen recorded gusts of up to  miles per hour battering the area... the highest wind speeds recorded for almost  years.Some terried residents of the three-storey flats at Middleshot Square, Prestonpans, fled as the roof began to rip off over their heads at around am, many still clad only in their nightwear.But amazingly others slept through the drama and only realised the danger when police and firemen hammered on their doors to evacuate the building.The back door had to be used, as the main entrance was blocked by giant roof sections.WHILEa community joined together to help a youngster.A -year-old Kenyan boy arrived in Haddington for an operation which could help change his le... thanks to a big fundraising effort by townsfolk.For they collected the pound, needed to bring Onesimus Mulwa to Scotland for surgery to have a huge disfiguring cyst removed from the side of his face.The connection with Haddington came about through Onesimusrsquos uncle, Ben Nzidka, who studied at Myreside School of Furniture Restoration at Gford.lsquoYODELLING cobblerrsquo was a headline in The Haddingtonshire Courier on November , .One of the more unusual acts on Hughie Greenrsquos ldquoOpportunity Knocks programme in recent years was that of a yodelling cobbler and his dancing shoes.The exponent of this act, Bill Gore, paid a visit to the Musselburgh Legion Club on Monday and gave an extended programme which illustrated why his performance justied the praise which it received.Supporting the artiste were the members of the resident Bon Accord Band, Allan Law , John Knoxand Ian Imrie.MAIL for residents of East Lothian was badly damaged, reported The Haddingtonshire Courier on November , .On Friday, an unaccountable accident took place in connection with the mail apparatus here, which receives the English bags by the London early morning train.The bags were much damaged and many of the letters were mutilated to such an extent as to make the establishment of the identity impossible.

title: new-magnet-fishing-group-set-musselburgh
story: James Pearson, , of Kilwinning Terrace, has formed Magnet Fishing Musselburgh and hopes to remove anything he sees that will cause harm to local wildle on the River Esk, such as shopping trolleys, bikes, scooters and other metal debris.ldquoIrsquove also retrieved a ladyrsquos purse which was handed into the police, he said.Mr Pearson, a former pupil of Musselburgh Burgh Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School, has been magnet fishing for about three years after watching the YouTube channel lsquoWW Wendalrsquo.ldquoI thought I would give it a try. I mainly fished by myself on the canals in Edinburgh, he explained.He then made contact with Magnet Fishing Edinburgh and, along with friends, created official Magnet Fishing Scotland, which, he said, was the only group worldwide to be legally allowed to magnet fish the Scottish canal system.Mr Pearson, a hire desk controller for a plant hire company, said: ldquoMagnet fishing has given me so many great friends and surprising finds, I thought I would create a group for my home town.ldquoI see this as giving something back to our brilliant community andit gets a few people out and into the fresh air then thatrsquos a bonus.He explained: ldquoMagnet fishing is tying a high-powered magnet onto a rope and throwing it into a body of water to remove any metallic items.ldquoItrsquos relatively inexpensive magnets range from pound to pound. Anyone can join in. You only need to get a magnet. You fish from the bank ndash I never advise going into the water. You donrsquot know the undercurrent of the water.ldquoI fish as much as I can but usually the weekends. I travel all over Britain magnet fishing.ldquoMy most unusual find was a hand gun I retrieved from the canal system in Glasgow.He added: ldquoMost of my finds are sent to the scrap-yard.Access the Magnet Fishing Musselburgh Facebook at facebook groups

title: tims-tales-learned-mozart
story: The tune had been a favourite of my father, who was very musically gted he played almost anything and everything from banjo and guitar to piano and organ. But his musical taste was very dferent to mine, although I did once manage to get him to sing along to Block Buster by the Sweet.My father died in August , just a week before I started high school at Preston Lodge. Irsquod just turned  years old. Soon afterwards, I remember going into his study, which had previously been out of bounds, and sitting in his chair, surrounded by his books, writing materials and music tapes.These were the days when combined radio and tape recorders were popular. His music tapes were in a special box, all titled in his handwriting. Hersquod recorded the music from the radio so the quality wasnrsquot brilliant.There were moments on the tapes when hersquod not switched it off quickly enough, so hersquod caught snippets of the presenter talking, and sometimes the tape had run out before the tune ended.But all this just made the tape collection a more powerful personal connection to my dad who Irsquod recently lost. So, while he had been unable to interest me in classical music while he was alive, I began to listen to his collection after his death. I would recognise tunes and was now able to put a name to them thanks to the titles hersquod written on the tapes.They conjured up memories for me. One was of a rainy Saturday afternoon in which my father invited me to join him in being the conductor for a Mozart tune. So he showed me how to conduct, leading and living the music with our arm movements. We had fun together doing this for what seemed like an hour or so in our small kitchen, as he explained the dferent instruments involved and how they merge together, and the role of the conductor. It was, in truth, a rare moment, but perhaps thatrsquos why I remembered it so vividly.It was the same Mozart tune that played on my car radio last week. It conjured another memory: of me standing in the kitchen being the conductor to the tune, alone, in the weeks after my fatherrsquos death. Irsquod found the tape and recognised the tune. I then learnt every pause, listened to the instruments and conducted to the music as my father had taught me.I didnrsquot understand it at the time, nobody spoke to me about it, but I now realise that I was in deep grief.My conducting the music was an expression of my loss, but I had nobody to talk to about it or process it I couldnrsquot allow the emotions to surface: ldquoBe strong, now you are the man of the family, boys donrsquot cry, they get on with it.My mother was stunned and closed down as well. I somehow learnt that tears, crying and being upset was something to avoid. So I buried my grief.So I did as advised, I got on with it. Irsquove done OK, I think, for I suppose when we walk with a stone in our shoe long enough we get used to it, and after a while stop noticing it. But, of course, it is still there, and only when we take our shoe off and finally find a way to remove the stone do we feel the dference and understand the effect itrsquos had on our walking.Last week was that moment for me: sitting in my car, overwhelmed with emotion from  years ago, remembering myself as a -year-old boy who felt he was unable to talk about what was then the greatest loss in his le.Irsquom a father myself now, of course, and thank goodness times have changed.There is a greater recognition these days of the need to talk, to express emotions and process feelings that our mental health is as important as our physical health, although words are often not matched with resources.But within our families also, we all need safe spaces to feel upset, let emotions surface and receive support from love ones. And that includes recognising our own mental health needs.I know most of us already know the importance of this. I certainly know it, yet despite this, I still tend to ignore the signs Irsquom struggling until my mental health is in tatters, which helps nobody.Just now my kids are having their own challenges, as so many are, and my own emotions have surfaced in my attempts to give support. The temptation was to quickly re-bury my emotions so I could concentrate on giving that support and also not let anyone down that voice is still in my head: ldquoGet on with it, man up.But that Mozart tune stopped me doing this. It made me connect with how I felt. It helped me understand why the adults close to me, when I was that -year-old boy, didnrsquot ask me how I was feeling or give me space and time to talk about my emotions and express my loss they couldnrsquot because they hadnrsquot allowed it for themselves.Mozart that day gave me the gt of self-care, which has helped me be more effective in caring and supporting loved ones, and ing at well at work.Itrsquos never easy to write about a personal vulnerability there is still that fear of ridicule. I had actually planned to write a historical tale this week, but events, and emotions, took over. There is always next time.Remembrance Day is this week, a time when we collectively pause to remember people we have lost in wars. Veterans know all about long-lasting trauma and loss, and the importance of acknowledging unseen emotional wounds.These issues can affect us all in dferent ways at dferent times. We rarely know the struggles that others are experiencing. Being kind to others includes being kind to yourself.

title: plans-360-centre-former-cockenzie-power-station-site
story: Councillors are to be asked to approve funding for a feasibility study into the development of the proposed  Centre, a community-led initiative to create a nationally important climate change centre.The  Centre is intended to be a major attraction for East Lothian, with proposals for a signicant art installation alongside a visitor centre, education and training facilities, as well as the potential to run ferry buses along the coast and marine trips from the adjacent pier.So far, the vacant former power station site, owned by East Lothian Council, has seen planning permission granted for offshore wind farm substations.The  Centre proposal is a community-led initiative which took shape last year and has since garnered pledges of support from residents, academic researchers and renewable energy developers.An online public launch event was conducted in April to gather community views, which have been incorporated into a draft vision document.The group behind the proposed plans will continue to seek community guidance and views through a series of events and an online survey.Anna Scott, a representative from the  Centre community group, said: ldquoWe are thrilled that East Lothian Council is engaging so constructively with our proposals and are hopeful that funding for a feasibility study will be approved.ldquoThe  Centre is an ambitious project, but why should we not be ambitious for the future of our local community ldquoAs a young person growing up in this coastal community, doing something positive to address the climate crisis just feels so important, not just for the future of our area but far beyond that.ldquoThe Cockenzie site is a site of hope ndash built on coal mines which stretch out under the Forth and the site of a former coal-fired power station which can now be reimagined to tell the story of climate change and even host research into solutions.ldquoThe  Centre would include iconic new sculptures and improve access to the site and the coastal pathway, which is of course named after the East Lothian-born environmentalist John Muir.ldquoOver  years ago, John Muir was creating national parks in America and inspiring others to value the earth and the nature around us. We want to bring a bit more of his legacy back to the area.ldquoAs Scotland hosts COP, we believe the  Centre is an opportunity for Cockenzie, Port Seton and Prestonpans to be at the heart of the solution to one of the greatest challenges we face ndash a project which could be of local, national and international importance in the story of climate change.ldquoWe want to be a part of the lsquowonderful recoveryrsquo which Sir David Attenborough spoke about so inspirationally when he addressed the opening session of the COP.Professor John Currie, director of the Scottish Energy Centre at Edinburgh Napier University, said: ldquoNowhere has such a facility been created with the aim of providing an attraction with such a vital educational message.Nikki Keddie, stakeholder manager for Inch Cape Offshore Wind Farm ndash which is to build a substation on another part of the site ndash said: ldquoThe  Centre is a visionary idea which could create a major visitor attraction in East Lothian, delivering new jobs and economic benefit for many years to come.ldquoItrsquos a terric opportunity for the local community to build on the arearsquos heritage whilst looking ahead to a sustainable low-carbon future, and as a close neighbour to the proposal, we are delighted to offer our support.

title: residents-asked-rate-services-council-survey
story: The survey, which is conducted independently, is an opportunity for people to tell East Lothian Council how they feel about their community, health, economic situation and public services.The council is also keen to hear how people have been affected by the ongoing Covid- pandemic.Councillor Norman Hampshire, depute council leader, encouraged people to take part in the survey.He said: ldquoThe last resident survey, in , highlighted very high levels of satisfaction with living in East Lothian.ldquoThe results provided us with useful intelligence on areas requiring focus, for example enabling people to better influence decisions and priorities for service improvement.ldquoLe as we knew it was then shaken up by Covid- and, while the ongoing pandemic continues to pose a risk to public health, as well as presenting major challenges to services and our communities, it is important that we give residents a fresh opportunity to have their say.ldquoThis is particularly important in helping the council, together with our partners, to plan for the future and ensure the people of East Lothian continue to benefit from high-quality, efficient services.Survey results will be confidential and anonymous and will inform East Lothian Councilrsquos strategies and priorities for the coming years.A sample of , residents across all areas will receive a postal survey, while anyone can complete it online at researchresource.welcomesyourfeedback.net s yyrwm

title: east-lothian-artists-new-exhibition-opens
story: Haddington-based artist Darren Woodheadrsquos new solo show lsquoClose to Homersquo is an ode to the natural world.Darren has exhibited widely and is an elected member of the Society of Wildle Artists.Ahead of the opening of the exhibition at the Scottish Ornithologistsrsquo Clubrsquos Waterston House, he said: ldquoAlthough the world has changed, my need to observe, document and record through watercolour has not.ldquoEven more so now, it is my escape, my sense of serenity and belonging.ldquoMany of the paintings have stemmed from observing birds in the garden or from lsquoone man on his bikersquo trips in the field.ldquoHere, I could immerse myself in the changing seasons and the parallel natural world, and feel the ultimate connection to my subject, close to home.The exhibition runs until January .

title: see-bonnie-babies-couriers-1-000-competition
story: In todays Courier print edition, we feature - for the last time - all the cute kids in the running for the pound first prize.Theyre so sweet that we just had to share them online too!The winner is the little one with the most votes after the final round - and votes can only be cast using the coupon published in this weeks Courier.So pick up a copy today! title: plant-tree-jubilee-discussions-taking-place
story: Patrick Gammell, one of the countyrsquos Deputy Lieutenants, will attend the townrsquos community council meeting this evening .Already plans are being drawn up to see trees planted throughout East Lothian.The Queenrsquos Green Canopyis a unique tree-planting initiative created to mark Her Majestyrsquos Platinum Jubilee in , which invites people from across the UK to lsquoPlant a Tree for the Jubileersquo.The community council is continuing to meet virtually, with the meeting getting under way at pm.

title: dozen-east-lothian-public-loos-temporarily-closing
story: The busiest public toilets, says East Lothian Council, will stay fully open, though  others will shut.Eight others will be limited to use of the disabled toilet only ndash which can be used by all.Tom Reid, the local authoritys head of infrastructure, said: ldquoWe continue to face extreme challenges due to a combination of staff absence ndash much of it Covid-related ndash as well as a high number of vacancies within our facilities management team.ldquoWe need to ensure our limited cleaning resources at this time are focused on keeping facilities such as schools clean, safe and fully open.ldquoWe appreciate this will be inconvenient and frustrating and we are grateful to communities for their patience and understanding at this dficult time.ldquoThe situation will be kept under review so that we can look to re-open facilities for the benefit of the public when it is practical.Toilets temporarily closing are:The toilets at Musselburgh Links remain closed as a result of fire damage.Locations where only disabled toilets will remain open for everyone to use daily are:Longniddry Bents car park No.SkaterawPort SetonMusselburgh, Fisherrow HarbourYellowcraigJohn Muir Country ParkDunbar, Shore RoadPrestonpansToilets remaining fully open seven days per weekare:
